artist: Artist: Tsukioka Yoshitoshi; Publisher: Tsunajima Kamekichi; Carver: Wada Yūjirō
catalogue_raissonne: Keyes, Courage and Silence (1982), no. 503.23; Iwakiri, Yoshitoshi (2014), fig. 281, p. 276.
creditline: The Mary Griggs Burke Endowment Fund established by the Mary Livingston Griggs and Mary Griggs Burke Foundation, gifts of various donors, by exchange, and gift of Edmond Freis in memory of his parents, Rose and Leon Freis
description: woman with white and purple irises behind her; woman wears Western dress, with a straw hat with black feathers and white flowers, pink and purple dress with purple and white plaid collar and large black buttons and blue tie at neckline; woman holds a Western style pink parasol with black handle and purple tassel with red bead
markings: Artist’s seal: たいそ {Taiso} | Carver’s seal: 彫工和田刀 {horikō Wada tō}
medium: Woodblock print (nishiki-e); ink and color on paper with embossing
portfolio: From Thirty-two Aspects of Behaviors (Fūzoku sanjūnisō 風俗三十二相)
text: In the final print of this nostalgic series, Yoshitoshi presents the future in a very modern-looking woman of his own time period and the only one in the set dressed in Western clothes. This married lady of the upper class is set against tall, blooming irises, indicating that the portrait depicts her during the month of May. She epitomizes the height of Western fashion, complete with bustle, buttons, bow tie, and parasol.
title: Appearing as if Having Been on a Stroll, Behavior of a Lady of the Meiji period
